fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.template

Class TemplateBuilderHelper<P>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.template.TemplateBuilderHelper<P>
  • Type Parameters:
    P - the type of the parent builder used by custom TemplateParser Builder

    public class TemplateBuilderHelper<P>
extends Object
    Helps to configure a TemplateParser builder.

    It registers and uses Builders to instantiate and configure TemplateParser specialized implementations.

    It also configures how to handle missing variant (either fail or do nothing).

    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Constructor Detail

      • TemplateBuilderHelper

        public TemplateBuilderHelper(P parent,
                             BuildContext buildContext)
        Initializes the builder with a parent builder. The parent builder is used when calling and() method of any registered TemplateParser Builder. The EnvironmentBuilder is used to evaluate properties at build time (used by TemplateParser Builders).
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent builder
        buildContext - for registering instances and property evaluation

    • Method Detail

      • hasRegisteredTemplates

        public boolean hasRegisteredTemplates()
        Indicates if some TemplateParser Builders have been registered
        Returns:
        true if at least one builder has been registered

      • failIfMissingVariant

        public TemplateBuilderHelper<P> failIfMissingVariant(Boolean fail)
        If a variant is missing, then force to fail.

        This may be useful if you want for example to always provide a text fallback when using an html template. So if a client can't read the html version, the fallback version will still always be readable. So to avoid forgetting to write text template, set this to true.

        The value set using this method takes precedence over any property and default value configured using failIfMissingVariant(). 

         .failIfMissingVariant(false)
 .failIfMissingVariant()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)
 
         .failIfMissingVariant(false)
 .failIfMissingVariant()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)
        In both cases, failIfMissingVariant(false) is used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If null value is set, it is like not setting a value at all. The property/default value configuration is applied.

        Parameters:
        fail - fail if a variant is missing
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • failIfMissingVariant

        public ConfigurationValueBuilder<TemplateBuilderHelper<P>,Boolean> failIfMissingVariant()
        If a variant is missing, then force to fail.

        This may be useful if you want for example to always provide a text fallback when using an html template. So if a client can't read the html version, the fallback version will still always be readable. So to avoid forgetting to write text template, set this to true.

        This method is mainly used by Configurers to register some property keys and/or a default value. The aim is to let developer be able to externalize its configuration (using system properties, configuration file or anything else). If the developer doesn't configure any value for the registered properties, the default value is used (if set). 

         .failIfMissingVariant()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)

        Non-null value set using failIfMissingVariant(Boolean) takes precedence over property values and default value. 

         .failIfMissingVariant(false)
 .failIfMissingVariant()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(true)
        The value false is used regardless of the value of the properties and default value.

        See ConfigurationValueBuilder for more information.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure property keys/default value

      • listPossiblePaths

        public TemplateBuilderHelper<P> listPossiblePaths(Boolean enable)
        When failIfMissingVariant() is enabled, also indicate which paths were tried in order to help debugging why a variant was not found.

        The value set using this method takes precedence over any property and default value configured using listPossiblePaths(). 

         .listPossiblePaths(true)
 .listPossiblePaths()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)
 
         .listPossiblePaths(true)
 .listPossiblePaths()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)
        In both cases, listPossiblePaths(true) is used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If null value is set, it is like not setting a value at all. The property/default value configuration is applied.

        Parameters:
        enable - enable/disable tracking of possible paths for template variants
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • listPossiblePaths

        public ConfigurationValueBuilder<TemplateBuilderHelper<P>,Boolean> listPossiblePaths()
        When failIfMissingVariant() is enabled, also indicate which paths were tried in order to help debugging why a variant was not found.

        This method is mainly used by Configurers to register some property keys and/or a default value. The aim is to let developer be able to externalize its configuration (using system properties, configuration file or anything else). If the developer doesn't configure any value for the registered properties, the default value is used (if set). 

         .listPossiblePaths()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)

        Non-null value set using listPossiblePaths(Boolean) takes precedence over property values and default value. 

         .listPossiblePaths(true)
 .listPossiblePaths()
   .properties("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}")
   .defaultValue(false)
        The value true is used regardless of the value of the properties and default value.

        See ConfigurationValueBuilder for more information.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure property keys/default value

      • missingVariant

        public void missingVariant(VariantResolver resolver)
        Provide custom resolver that will handle a missing variant.
        Parameters:
        resolver - the custom resolver

      • register

        public <B extends Builder<? extends TemplateParser>> B register(Class<B> builderClass)
        Registers and configures a TemplateParser through a dedicated builder. For example: 
         .register(ThymeleafEmailBuilder.class)
     .detector(new ThymeleafEngineDetector());

        Your Builder may implement VariantBuilder to handle template Variants (used for MultiTemplateContent that provide a single path to templates with different extensions for example).

        Your Builder may also implement DetectorBuilder in order to indicate which kind of templates your TemplateParser is able to parse. If your template parse is able to parse any template file you are using, you may not need to implement DetectorBuilder.

        In order to be able to keep chaining, you builder instance may provide a constructor with two arguments:

        • The type of the parent builder (&lt;P&gt;)
        • The EnvironmentBuilder instance
        If you don't care about chaining, just provide a default constructor.
        Type Parameters:
        B - the type of the builder
        Parameters:
        builderClass - the builder class to instantiate
        Returns:
        the builder to configure the implementation

      • buildTemplateParser

        public TemplateParser buildTemplateParser()
        Build the template parser according to options previously enabled. If only one template engine has been activated then the parser will be this template engine parser. If there are several activated engines, then the builder will generate an AutoDetectTemplateParser. This kind of parser is able to detect which parser to use according to the provided template at runtime. The auto-detection is delegated to each defined TemplateEngineDetector associated with each engine.
        Returns:
        the template parser instance
        Throws:
        BuildException - when template parser couldn't be initialized

      • buildVariant

        public VariantResolver buildVariant()
        Instantiates and configures the variant resolution. Variant resolution is a chain of resolvers. The first resolver that is able to resolve a variant is used. If no resolver is able to resolve a variant, it uses the default variant resolver (see failIfMissingVariant(Boolean) and missingVariant(VariantResolver)).
        Returns:
        the variant resolver
